p: In human skin, the first human organs supporting viral replication upon a mosquito bite, the dermal fibroblasts, constitute the main site of viral amplification, as demonstrated in vitro [ 139, 140, 141], in mice models (IFN-type-I receptors deficient or neonates animals), and by the detection of viral antigens in a skin biopsy from a neonatal fatal case [ 142]. In these cells, CHIKV infection determines a strong antiviral IFN-type-I (IFN-I) response, alongside the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines. The induction of many antiviral genes (e.g., viral sensors, IFN-I receptors, and IFN stimulated genes (ISGs)) is however contrasted by components of Aedes mosquito saliva, thus favoring viral replication [ 141].
